comments.body: Add the specific language name in the 'language_facet' .

We aren't always guaranteed to be able to find the more general language name (the "macrolanguage" using ISO 639-3 terminology) given a certain ISO 639-3 code.

The provided example, `wuu`, is included in the [ISO 639-3 macrolanguage table](https://iso639-3.sil.org/sites/iso639-3/files/downloads/iso-639-3-macrolanguages.tab) with a macrolanguage of `zho` (Chinese).  In the example MARC record, the 008 contains the ISO 639-2B code `chi` (Chinese), so we could also generate the requested facet "Chinese" from that.

However, another example: `nuz` (Tlamacazapa Nahuatl) isn't mapped to a macrolanguage of Nahuatl, since no such macrolanguage exists in ISO 639-3 (it does in ISO-639-2 and ISO-639-1).  It seems that we would want both "Tlamacazapa Nahuatl" and "Nahuatl" in the facets -- will CaMS catalogers always put in both the ISO 639-3 and 639-2B code in these records?

Some possible gems:

* https://github.com/bbenno/languages -- it does not currently include macrolanguages and has not yet had a version 1.0.0 release, but does have CI and a nice script for updating the code data.
* https://github.com/mlj/iso-codes -- on version 1.2.0, tests but no CI, does include macrolanguages

We could also forego using an additional gem, and use the [debian iso-codes package](https://packages.debian.org/sid/iso-codes) or [the tables directly from SIL](https://iso639-3.sil.org/code_tables/download_tables).

Also noting that, while we currently use the `language_facet` field for both the facet and the show page, we'll have to use two separate fields (and do the appropriate orangelight work) in order to meet these requirements.

Also, for the facet display, do we want them to be presented as a list, or as a "pivot facet" like the call number facet?

ProQuest was unable to make an ssh key that works with our systems, so they're going to set up access for us to pull these off of their SFTP server next.

> 
> Thanks for confirming! Deron and I will work on getting this created for you and will let you know as soon as it's accessible.
> 
> Thanks!
> Maddie
> 
>

> Typed with my thumbs. Please excuse brevity & typos.
>

>  
> ﻿
> Good morning Francis,
> 
>  
> 
> The ssh client on our delivery server is too old to support ed25519. The O/S is CentOs 6.5 and our client is 5.3. As I mentioned yesterday, we are actively working on provisioning new hardware to replace our current infrastructure. I anticipate that is still a couple of weeks from being operational.
> 
>  
>

> 
>  
> 
> Let me know,
> 
> Deron

figgy.title: MIgrate Numismatic::Accession date values to "YYYY-MM-DD" strings

comments.body:
Mockups: 
* simpler mockup with most updated visual elements: https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1tq2JOyoO4_xf_ORGUf39tByk9_0VOUpO0GECC-tyD-Y/edit
* More comments on this mockup: https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1oa_CxDqRZK4jlkPJA9x3uyolQUYkdBTlF_p9hPlB5hM/edit

Implementation notes:
* We need a concept of "list-focus" that's different from "selected" or "expanded"
* We need both "selectable" and "expandable." Figgy will mark every directory as "expandable."
* We need to figure out how to get the data from the modal into the form
  * Use a 4th component that lives on the page and renders the modal and the other components, populates the values when the modal is closed.
* We need 3 vue components, one container to hold the data and other two, then the directory pane and the list pane.
  * parent pane holds which directory is the "list-focus" item, when that data variable has a value the list pane populates.
  * initializes the directory pane with everything that's expandable.
  * In the directory pane, if you click an item it sends a list-focus event to the container.
  * If you click "select all" the list pane fires a selection event.
  * If you click a directory name in the left does it expand it?

All data is held in the root/container. The child components fire events up and the container component manages the data updates.

Some outstanding questions:
* If I click the title of a directory, does it expand or just list-focus?
  * in drive, it does not expand. just list-focus.
* If I expand a directory, does it also list-focus that directory?
  * in drive, no.

comments.body:
Extremely long contents fields cause many other problems as well. This doesn't impact the ticket, but I am planning on sweeping through all records periodically to locate fields that are longer than 9,999 bytes.

The byte limit for an individual field in the MARC standard is 9,999 bytes. The byte limit for a record is 99,999 bytes.

There is an option in the ruby-marc gem to allow oversized records, but I don't know if that would really solve this (since it would result in an invalid MARC file).

Perhaps you could check the record before serving it up to see if the record is too large to export in binary format?

This is code I use to find problems like this:

```
def record_size?(record)
    total_size = 0
    total_size += record.leader.bytesize if record.leader
    record.fields.each do |field|
      total_size += 1 # field separator character
      total_size += field.tag.bytesize
      if field.class == MARC::ControlField
        total_size += field.value.bytesize
      else
        field.subfields.each do |subfield|
          total_size += subfield.code.bytesize
          total_size += subfield.value.bytesize
          total_size += 1 # subfield separator character
        end
      end
    end
    total_size > 99999
  end

  def field_size?(record)
    return true if record.leader.bytesize != 24

    record.fields.each do |field|
      if field.class == MARC::ControlField
        return true if field.value.bytesize > 9999

      else
        total_size = 0
        field.subfields.each do |subfield|
          total_size += subfield.code.bytesize
          total_size += 1 # subfield separator character
          total_size += subfield.value.bytesize
        end
        return true if total_size > 9999

      end
    end
    false
  end
```
